data.text: Contents
Introduction

The aim of this policy is to provide an agreed approach to the effective implementation of the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DoLS). DoLS apply to adults over 18 years and is a legal framework to protect adults who require hospital treatment but lack capacity to make an informed decision to remain in hospital. This policy has been updated at a time when there is a national review and replacement of DoLS proposed. The new legislation and pending guidance on the DoLS replacements to Liberty Protection Safeguards' (LPS) is currently scheduled for implementation in 2022 as part of the Mental Capacity (Amendment) Act, 2019. The revised changes are acknowledged and welcomed for the new LPS and will provide a legal framework and protection to people aged 16 years and above.
However, this policy reflects the current legislative guidelines which will be reviewed again at a later date, once the LPS is brought into force and implemented at a time directed by Government.

This policy provides local guidance for MSE Staff alongside the SET (Southend, Essex and Thurrock) Mental Capacity Act Policy and the DoLS Code of Practice and the SET Safeguarding Adults Guidance. The aim of this policy is to provide guidance local guidance on the legal framework to protect vulnerable adults who lack capacity to make an informed decision to remain in hospital for the purpose of being given necessary care or treatment. This means MSE staff can prevent a person from leaving the hospital where they are being given the care they need in their best interests. It also makes it lawful for the Trust to keep a patient under continuous supervision and control in their best interest, to protect them from potential and foreseeable harm. Staff should also have an understanding of restrictive interventions within the workplace (Policy for the Management of Challenging behaviour & Restrictive Interventions).

Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards provide legal protection for those vulnerable people who are, or may become, deprived of their liberty within the meaning of Article 5 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) in a hospital or care home. The safeguards were introduced through amendments to the Mental Capacity Act 2005. They do not apply to people already detained under the Mental Health Act 1983. If in doubt staff should seek advice from the Adult Safeguarding Team or the Local Authority. Failure to apply a DoLS appropropriately for patients that meet the statutory criteria could result in an unlawful deprivation.

The safeguards provide a framework for authorising the deprivation of liberty for individuals who lack the capacity to consent to the arrangements for their treatment or care that, in their own best interests, can only be provided in circumstances that amount to a deprivation of liberty. DoLS are a vital tool to ensure that the Trust is acting in the best interest of the patient and all staff must be made aware that the DoLS framework is a legal one. A deprivation of liberty does not apply to individuals detained under the Mental Health Act 1983: Code of Practice (2008) as although a deprivation of liberty is evident the legislative powers are not the same. For further clarity, MSE staff are reassured that they can always seek advice from the Adult Safeguarding Team or the Local Authority.
The safeguards aim to:
Ensure that people can be given the care and support they need in the least restrictive environment
Prevent arbitrary decisions that deprive people of their liberty
Provide safeguards for vulnerable people who lack capacity
Provide people with rights of challenge against unlawful detention
Avoid unnecessary bureaucracy
Provide safeguards for staff caring for people in the hospital
Scope
The purpose of this document is :
To set out the responsibilities of staff in the recognition of a patient that may be deprived of their liberty whilst in the care of the Trust to receive medical intervention.
To clearly set out the actions required in the patients best interest within the legal framework of Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards.
To ensure staff feel supported in the implementation and application of a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard.
This policy applies to patients / service users aged 18 and over who:
Have an impairment or disturbance in the functioning of the persons mind or brain, whether temporary or permanent.
Are cared for in a hospital or care home for the purpose of being given care or treatment.
Lack the capacity to give informed consent to the arrangements made for their care and/or treatment
It is considered, after an independent assessment, to be necessary in their best interests to deprive them of their liberty, to protect them from harm.
Situations for which a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard does not apply include:
Circumstances for protection of others and should only apply to the individual.
The Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards does not apply to people detained in hospital under the Mental Health Act 1983.
Definitions

table_items.text: This is a decision to refuse specified treatment. The decision is made in advance by a person who at the time of making the decision has capacity to do so. The decision will then apply at a future time when that person lacks capacity to consent to, or refuse, the specified treatment.

Someone who has undergone training and received a qualification as a best interest assessor, and is able to assess whether or not deprivation of liberty is in the person's best interests, and is necessary to prevent harm to the person and is a proportionate response to the likelihood and seriousness of that harm.

The Deprivation of liberty safeguards (DoLS) are a legal framework that exist to ensure that individuals who lack the mental capacity to consent to the arrangements for their care, where such care may (because of restrictions imposed on an individual's freedom of choice or movement) amount to a ‘deprivation of liberty', have the arrangements independently assessed to ensure they are in the best interests of the individual concerned. The person appointed under a lasting power of attorney who has the legal right to make decisions within the scope of their authority on behalf of the person (the donor) who made the lasting power of attorney.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
MSE Chief Nurse
The Chief Nurse, as Executive Lead for Safeguarding, has responsibility for:
Ensuring that The Trust Board / Executive is aware of, and discharges its statutory safeguarding duties, Including adherence to the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (Including DoLS).
Ensuring the MSE Group, has complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirement are in line with the Mental Capacity Act 2005.
Reporting of safeguarding / MCA issues to the Joint Executive Group.
Clinical Directors
Clinical Directors are responsible for
Ensuring that policies and procedures are communicated and implemented across the Directorates / Divisions / Care Groups.
Incorporating relevant aspects of the Policy into local induction arrangements
Nominating a representative to sit on the MSE Safeguarding Committee in Common where MSE compliance to the Mental Capacity Act 2005 will be monitored.
Implementing and supporting the monitoring of action plans generated to support the work of the Safeguarding / MCA agenda.
Ensuring that staff involved in supporting patients with decision making have access to appropriate training, policies ,advice and support.
Ensuring that DoLS are embedded into practice.
Deputy Chief Nurse (with MSE Responsibility for Safeguarding)
Delegated responsivity for ensuring the implementation and delivery of policies and procedures to safeguard adults at risk and the implementation and use of the Mental Capacity Act, including:
Oversight of MCA / DoLS decision making practice within the Trust.
Monitoring the effectiveness of the DoLS process and provide assurance to the Board, via the Chief Nurse, that the Trust is meeting its duty under the Mental Capacity Act.
To champion safeguarding (including DoLS) and promoting the welfare of adults and children throughout the organisation.
MSE Associate Director for Safeguarding Service
Responsible for

The development and leadership of a culture of safeguarding, mental capacity, DoLS and best practice across the Trust, providing strategic and corporate direction including complex professional advice on matters relating to safeguarding individuals at risk and / or assessment of capacity and decision making.

Leading the Trust on collaborative working practices across agency and geographical boundaries, with providers of health and social care and other partner agencies, to provide a seamless approach to assessment of capacity in the context of patient care.

Promoting early and accurate identification and management of concerns where an individual is at risk of being deprived of their liberty, in relation to mental capacity assessment by professional leadership, expert practice, research and education.
Ensuring that national and local recommendations are implemented across the Trust and are included within its policies and practice.

Leading a robust culture of safeguarding, directed through the approved MSE safeguarding governance reporting structure, including the Safeguarding Operational Groups, Learning Disabilities Operational Group and the Children and Adults Safeguarding Committee.
Providing expert advice to staff across MSE on all matters of mental capacity and decision making, including the application of DoLS.
Demonstrating advanced skills and competencies to influence the pathways of care when capacity is a factor for consideration and an individual is at risk of being deprived of their liberty.
Initiating and add to research evidence in the field of safeguarding and adherence with legislative processes to ensure that evidence-based practice is inherent in all aspects of care.
Ensuring a safeguarding audit programme is in place which provides assurance that safeguarding systems and processes are working effectively to support and facilitate learning from practice.
Liaising with legal experts as required.
Acting as a consultative resource across the Trust covering all aspects relating to DoLS and provide expert advice on on the proportionate application of a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard.
Updating this policy in line with changing requirements and legislation (local and national)
Ensuring that the provision of training on the Mental Capacity Act (including DoLS) is available to all staff as identified in the mapping of staff according to role.
Monitoring the quality and uptake of training.
Ensuring that Trust information systems are regularly revised and updated in line with Government directives.
Named Nurse for Safeguarding Adults
Responsible for:
Updating this policy in line with changing requirements and supporting staff to apply the principles of the policy in practice.
Ensuring that the provision of training provided on the Mental Capacity Act is made available to all staff within the organisation as identified in the Training Needs Analysis.
Monitoring and evaluating delivery and update of training.
Monitor and assure the application of MCA and DoLS guidance within the Trust.
Ensuring mental capacity / DoLS is considered appropriately within the safeguarding of adults at risk.
Responding effectively to any concerns raised regarding the potential deprivation of liberty of an individual in our care. Provides advice consistent with national and local expectations.
Ensuring effective databases are maintained and quality assurance processes are in place.
Attending necessary local safeguarding / MCA forums (including any forums that come under the remit of safeguarding) and disseminate information accordingly.
Ensuring relevant / up to date information is disseminated.
To support lead clinicians in their responsibility for making best interest decisions or on any issues or queries related to the Mental Capacity Act, including DoLS.
Named Doctor for Safeguarding Adults
Responsible for
Championing all aspects of safeguarding within the Trust and provide expert medical advice, including advise on mental capacity assessment.
Providing specialist advice and co-ordination.
Working alongside the Safeguarding Team and contribute to compliance to the Trusts safeguarding duties, including DoLS, best interest decision making and mental capacity assessment.
Attending relevant forums, and disseminate information accordingly
Support in the dissemination and application of updated information / practice requirements.
Assisting in the promotion of training compliance for medical staff.
Safeguarding Adults Nurses (Site role)
The Safeguarding Adults Nurses have delegated responsibility to:
Provide support and training to staff in the implementation of the mental Capacity Act 2005 within all service areas.
Alert risk management via incident management systems when the mental capacity Act 2005, including DoLS is not correctly applied.
Contribute towards the setting, monitoring and maintenance of robust mental capacity / best interest decision making arrangements policies and practice.
Contribute to collaborative interagency working and quality assurance frameworks by ensuring representation at Safeguarding Adults Boards / partnerships and subgroups.
Provide expert clinical leadership and direction for service users and staff.
Site Directors of Nursing, Heads of Nursing, Matrons, Ward Sisters/ Charge Nurses, Allied Health Professionals, Team Leaders and all Health Professionals
Responsible for

The implementation and application of this policy across their divisions / services / Care Groups and ensuring staff attend the appropriate training to enable them to work within the principles of this policy.
To ensure there are staff have the knowledge and understand of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and identify and respond to any gaps in knowledge / practice.
To ensure all staff have a working knowledge of the application of the Mental Capacity Act and how to seek advice if required.
All Staff Responsibilities:
Regardless of grade or position be aware of this policy and to apply policy according to role.

If there is evidence to suggest that an individual may not be able to make a specific decision, this should be discussed with the medical staff so that a mental capacity assessment can be undertaken. If it is proven that the individual does not have capacity to make the decision to remain in hospital to receive treatment, the person is subject to continuous control and supervision and is not free to leave then a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard (DoLS) Application must be completed and sent to the Adult Safeguarding Team and copy of the DoLS application should be filed in patients' medical notes.
To ensure the staff member knows where to find DoLS policy and forms, and familiarise themselves with the contents.
Report any concerns on unsafe practice to the Trust Adult Safeguarding Team.
Completing relevant mandatory training in relation according to their role.
Ensuring they know the principles of best interest decision making and its application in practice.

Adult and Child Safeguarding Operational Groups  oversee all operational safeguarding activity (including the application of the Mental Capacity Act and DoLS guidance) including training compliance and adherence to policies.

MSE Group Adult and Child Safeguarding Committee oversees assurance to the Trust Board that policies, systems and procedures and in place, disseminated and adhered to, to safeguard children, young people and adults at risk. Provides assurance on the implementation, monitoring and updating of policies, systems, and procedures within the Trust for safeguarding children, young people, and adults at risk. Responding to changes in local and national guidance, legislation, and best practice.

The Trust Board / Executive Committee has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust makes an effective contribution towards inter-agency working with partner agencies and for appropriately prioritising all aspects of safeguarding (including Mental Capacity Act 2005) safeguarding adults at risk and its allocation of resources for service and professional training and development. This includes representation at Safeguarding Adult Board Meetings / Partnerships and Subgroups. The Board has nominated the Chief Nurse and Director of Nursing to be responsible for assuring the safety and welfare of adults at risk, and for updating the relevant policies and ensuring that the necessary procedures are available for all staff
DoLS Procedural Guidelines
General DoLS Principles to be applied
5.1.1 Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards applies to adults over the age of 18 years.
5.1.2 All individuals, regardless of age, ability, race, gender, sexual orientation, faith or beliefs should have the greatest possible control over their lives.

5.1.3 The Mental Capacity Act states that a person aged 16 and over must be assumed to have capacity unless it is established that they lack capacity. However DoLS only applies to individuals over the age of 18.

5.1.4 People have a right to express their wishes and priorities and to be personally involved when plans are made for their care or treatment. Every effort should be made to enable people to make decisions and express their wishes in a way that is appropriate for them and to maximise their participation in a decision-making process.
5.1.5 A person must not be treated as unable to make a decision merely because they make an unwise decision.

5.1.6 Where it has been shown that a person lacks capacity, any act done, or decisions made for or on behalf of that person must be done or made in their best interests. How that best interest decision has been reached must be evidenced.
5.1.7 Before an act is done or a decision is made on behalf of a person who has been shown to lack capacity, regard must be shown as to whether the purpose for which
it is needed can be as effectively achieved in a way that is less restrictive of the person's rights and freedom of action.

5.1.8 Every effort should be made, in both commissioning and for providing care or treatment, to prevent a deprivation of liberty. If a deprivation cannot be avoided it should be for no longer than is necessary.
5.1.9 All adults have the right, as individuals:
To be free from abuse from care givers or fellow users.
To live as normally as possible in an environment where individuality, independence, privacy and personal dignity are respected.
An individual's right to make decisions for themselves must be balanced with their right to be protected from harm if they lack capacity to make decisions to protect themselves.

5.1.10 All staff should work within the principles of the Mental Capacity Act (MCA), for example by doing everything possible to empower people to make as many decisions for themselves as they can. Staff should be aware of the 5 principles of mental capacity (Mental Capacity Act Policy 2005).

5.1.11 Care plans for individuals lacking mental capacity to agree to arrangements for their care or treatment should show evidence of best interest decision making in accordance with the Mental Capacity Act, based on decision-specific capacity assessments. Plans of care are an essential tool for demonstrating the proportionate restrictive interventions are in place in the best interest of the individual.

5.1.12 All assessments and approvals of Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards applications are carried out in accordance with local processes, with regard to the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Code of Practice (2008).
5.1.13 All processes and practices within the Trust should be written to ensure that no adult is deprived of their liberty unlawfully.
5.1.14 Trust policies must reflect the agreed approach with the CCG and partner Local Authorities, to ensure a co-ordinated approach.

5.1.15 All key participants in the deprivation of liberty must be aware of and perform their roles and statutory responsibilities and have regard to the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Code of Practice.
5.1.16 The Supreme Court (2014) ruled that the following factors are not relevant to whether or not someone is deprived of their liberty:
The person's compliance or happiness or lack of objection to an act that could be considered as a deprivation of liberty.

The  suitability  or  relative  normality  of  the  placement  (after  comparing  the person's circumstances with another person of similar age and condition); or the reason or purpose leading to a particular placement
Recognising when an individual may be at risk of being deprived of their liberty
5.2.1 There are two main elements to a deprivation of liberty for an individual (over 18 years of age) that does not have capacity, also known as the Acid Test (Supreme Court 2014):
Is the person subject to continuous control and supervision?
The oversight should be continuous though this does not have to mean in the line of sight, it should amount to supervision and have a clear element of control.
Is the person free to leave?

5.2.2 The person may not be asking to leave or be showing by their actions that they want to leave, but it is an understanding and awareness of how staff would react if the person did try to leave or if relatives / friends asked to discharge the person. If the response would be likely to include a significant restrictive intervention to maintain the individual in hospital then this may meet the DoLS thresh-hold.

5.2.3 Professionals must consider the continuous supervision and control likely to be required, and the reaction of staff if the person did try to leave or someone tried to remove them and if this would amount to a deprivation.
5.2.4 Staff must understand that the application of a DoLS must only be for individuals that lack capacity. A DoLS for an individual deemed to have capacity would be an unlawful use of the framework.
Consideration of Capacity: Applying the Mental Capacity Act 2005

5.3.1 The Mental Capacity Act 2005 provides the legal framework for acting and making decisions on behalf of individuals who lack the mental capacity to make particular decisions for themselves. Everyone working with and/or caring for any person aged 16 years or over, who may lack capacity to make specific decisions, must comply with the mental Capacity Act 2005 when making decisions or acting in the best interest of the person.

5.3.2 All Deprivation of Liberty applications (18 years or over) must be accompanied by an assessment of the individual's capacity to make a decision as to whether or not to remain in hospital or a care environment to receive specified treatment and care. A DoLS applied to an individual that has capacity would be an illegal application of the framework.
The application of a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard

5.4.1 Under the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DoLS) guidance, Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is the Managing Authority and has a statutory duty to make formal requests for authorisation to deprive patients of their liberty, when they believe the “acid test” described in section  has been met and  continuous control or supervision is required.

5.4.2 In clinical areas such as Emergency Departments, the guidance is that “staff can act reasonably to get beyond the point of crisis”. Therefore after the patient has been medically stabilised and there is a reasonable belief that continuous control or supervision may be required, then the patient may have reached the thresh hold of a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard.

5.4.3 Intensive Care Settings: Guidance states no deprivation of liberty in respect of life saving treatment and treatment within intensive care settings are not considered a deprivation. However, if a patients behaviour becomes challenging then services should seek advice and consider if a DoLS would be suitable and in the best interest of the patient.

5.4.4 Before giving an authorisation for a deprivation of liberty, the Supervisory Body must be satisfied that a number of conditions have been met. However, the Managing Authority can apply an Urgent Deprivation of Liberty for 1 week (2 weeks with an extension) until the Local Authority have carried out the necessary assessments to ensure the required conditions have been met.

5.4.5 The decision of a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard is a matter of law and depends on the particular circumstances of each case. As a general rule, to determine whether there has been a Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards, it is useful to look at a whole range of factors including:
Type of deprivation
Duration of deprivation
Effects and manner of implementation of the measure in question.
The DoLS application process
Urgent & Standard Authorisations Form 1 (Appendix 3)

5.5.1 In an emergency, the hospital (Managing Authority) may issue themselves an urgent authorisation to deprive someone (that does not have capacity) of their liberty. In the Urgent Authorisation they must state their reasons for applying the safeguard, include the treatment plan, what is the impairment of the mind, the restraint / restriction in place and why the patient needs to remain in hospital. The form 1 must then be sent to the to the Local Authority (Supervisory Body). An Urgent Authorisation can be made to the Local Authority for a period of 7 days. An extension of the Urgent DoLS can be can be made to the supervisory body (Local Authority) for a further 7 days in exceptional circumstances. Anyone with a concern, e.g. a family member, can apply to the supervisory body to raise a concern about the application of an Urgent DoLS application.

5.5.2 An Urgent Authorisations can never be made without a simultaneous application for a standard authorisation to the Supervisory Body. The Managing Authority must inform the Supervisory Body when an extension is needed and only one such extension can be granted. Both the Urgent and Standard Authorisation can now be applied by the completion of a Form 1 application (Appendix 3).
5.5.3 The Managing Authority (The Trust) can apply an Urgent DoLS and also apply for a standard authorisation if they believe the acid test has been met.

5.5.4 Any Trust professional with direct involvement with the individual can complete a DoLS application using a Form 1 (appendix 3). When completed, the Form 1 must then be sent to the Adult Safeguarding Team DoLS / MCA Administrator to be quality assured on behalf of the Trust before it is sent to the Supervisory Body (Local Authority):
shn-tr.msb.dolsmca@nhs.net

5.5.5 The Supervisory Body will appoint a Best Interest Assessor (BIA) to ascertain if the required conditions have been met to allow the person to be deprived of their liberty under the safeguards (see appendix 4). The required conditions include:
The person is 18 or over (different safeguards apply for children).
The person is suffering from an impairment or disturbance in the functioning of the person's mind or brain.
The person lacks capacity to decide for themselves about the restrictions which are proposed so they can receive the necessary care and treatment.
The restrictions would deprive the person of their liberty.
The proposed restrictions would be in the person's best interests.
Whether the person should instead be considered for detention under the Mental Health Act.
There is no valid advance decision to refuse treatment or support that would be overridden by any DoLS process.

5.5.6 If any of the conditions are not met, the deprivation of liberty cannot be authorised. This may mean that the care home or hospital has to change its care plan so that the person can be supported in a less restrictive way. If all conditions are met, the Supervisory Body must authorise the deprivation of liberty and inform the person and Managing Authority in writing including the length of time the authorisation has been approved for, and any conditions in place.
Documentation

5.6.1 The need to make and keep written records comes from several sources: the Mental Capacity Act 2005, regulations made under the Act, and the Code of Practice. Some records and forms are necessary because the procedures involve depriving a fellow citizen of their liberty. These records can be requested in a court of law and must be correctly completed. Carefully and systematically recording how this was done is an important safeguard, and consequently an important part of the law, good practice and concern for the welfare of others.

5.6.2 Completing these forms and records also enables supervisory bodies and assessors to demonstrate that they acted lawfully if their actions are later challenged. Their completion should be viewed as a way of helping them to practice safely within the law, so that necessary care or treatment can be provided without unnecessary fear of legal liability.

5.6.3 Staff must be aware that poor completion of the necessary Form 1 DoLS Urgent and Standard Authorisation can cause a delay in the legal application of the safeguard and also lead to a challenge that the DoLS has not been applied in the best interest of the individual. A DoLS application will also be declined if not accompanied with an appropriate mental capacity assessment.
What happens when a DoLS authorisation is granted?

5.7.1 Not every assessment process will result in an authorisation. However, once a person in a hospital has a DoLS authorisation, a relevant person's representative (RPR) must be appointed to support them and look after their interests. (The Best Interest Assessor in the Local Authority will identify this person)
5.7.2 The Managing Authority (together with its Supervisory Body) should:
Make regular checks to see if the authorisation is still necessary
Remove the authorisation when it is no longer necessary (Form 9 on Staffnet)
Provide the patients relevant persons representative with information about the care and treatment of the person who has a DoLS authorisation.
What does the Act mean by ‘restraint'?
5.8.1 Section 6 of the Act states that someone is using restraint if they:
Use force, or threaten to use force to make someone do something that they are resisting, or
Restrict a person's freedom of movement, whether they are resisting or not.

5.8.2 Staff must refer to local policies on Management of Challenging Behaviour and the use of Restrictive Interventions for further guidance on the use of restraint and restriction within the Trust and refer to appendix 5 for guidance on the use of hand control mittens
Transferring someone to another hospital or a care home

5.9.1 Transporting a person who lacks capacity from their home, or another location, to a hospital or care home will not usually amount to a deprivation of liberty (for example, to take them to hospital by ambulance in an emergency.) Even where there is an expectation that the person will be deprived of liberty within the care home or hospital.

5.9.2 It is unlikely that the journey itself will constitute a deprivation of liberty. In almost all cases, it is likely that a person can be lawfully taken to a hospital or a care home under the wider provisions of the Act, as long as it is considered that being in the hospital or care home will be in their best interests.

5.9.3 It is the responsibility of Trust staff to inform a new care provider if a patient is transferred or discharged to another care environment if the individual has been on a DoLS whilst in the care of the Trust. It is up to the new provider to apply for a DoLS when the patient transfers into their care. Trust staff must apply for the discontinuation of the DoLS by completing a Form  The Trust Adult Safeguarding Team / MCA & DoLS Administrator must also be informed.
When should an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA) be instructed?

5.10.1 If there is nobody appropriate to consult, other than people paid to provide care or treatment for the relevant person in a professional capacity, the Managing Authority must notify the Supervisory Body when it submits the application (Form 1) for the deprivation of liberty authorisation. The supervisory body must then instruct an IMCA straight away to represent the person. It is particularly important that the IMCA is instructed quickly if an urgent authorisation has been given, so that they can make a meaningful input at a very early stage in the process.
5.10.2 Other circumstances in which an IMCA must or may be instructed
5.10.3 An IMCA may be instructed at any time where:
the relevant person does not have a paid ‘professional'
representative
the relevant person or their representative requests that an IMCA is
Instructed to help them, or
a supervisory body believes that instructing an IMCA will help to ensure that the person's rights are protected.
Training requirements
All staff are responsible for attending adult safeguarding training or completing the approved eLearning training programme that includes DoLS and mental capacity,

data.text: By reviewing all DoLS applications the Adult Safeguarding Team will monitor the following are in place:
Clear  identification  of  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  all  participants, including managing and supervisory bodies, in the process.
Agreed protocols and processes about when and how to apply for authorisations.
Agreed protocols and processes for managing cross-boundary applications.
Guidance on time limits on key stages of the process for both standard and urgent authorisations that ensure all stakeholders meet their statutory obligations.
Guidance on the roles of IMCAs and representatives and how referrals should be made.
Transparent internal processes that outline how and who authorises assessments.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Safeguarding Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local safeguarding guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Safeguarding Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 2 Deprivation of liberty screening checklist – for use by managing authorities
To be used in conjunction with DoLS Flowchart 1 Appendix 2:

To be used with the MCA DoLS Application Process Flowchart above. The checklist has been designed to help staff identify where someone is being deprived of their liberty, and their care plan requires an urgent review. Where a deprivation of liberty is occurring it is illegal unless authorised by the CCG

table_items.text: The following questions should be considered about each person in a care home or hospital
ward who doesn't have the capacity to give informed consent to being there.
Section ONE: How the person was admitted to the hospital
Is the person currently cared for in hospital?
Yes / No: If Yes then proceed
Does the person lack capacity to consent to the arrangements for their care?
Yes / No: If Yes then proceed
Is it possible the person could be detained under the MH Act?
Yes / No : If yes request an assessment. Under MHA
Does the person have a LPA or COP order?
Yes / No If Yes Involve Donee or Court Deputy
Was force or sedatives used because the person was resisting being admitted? Does not include the use of benign force, such as gently guiding someone by the arm.
YES / NO ; If Yes Urgently review care plan or consider DOL
Was the person deceived to make sure they co-operated? For instance were they misled into believing that they would return home the next day?
YES / NO If Yes Urgently review care plan or consider DOL
Did the person's relatives, or carers who live with the person, object to them being admitted?
YES / NO If Yes Urgently review care plan and make a request for DOL

Is the person sedated to prevent them leaving? Use of sedatives does not in itself mean that a person is deprived of liberty – it is only relevant if the purpose is to prevent the person from leaving the establishment.
YES / NO If Yes Urgently review care plan or consider DOL

Does the person make persistent or purposeful attempts to leave, which are prevented by means of force or a locked door? A locked door does not constitute deprivation on its own, even if its purpose is to prevent residents from wandering. Likewise for the use of benign force, such as gently guiding someone by the arm to return them when they are wandering. This test is met only if the person's attempts to leave are persistent and/or purposeful.
YES / NO If Yes Urgently review care plan or consider DOL/ Or urgent psychiatry assessment. ? section under the MHA

Is force being used to treat the person when they are resisting, other than in an emergency? Use of benign force to administer medication, or to feed or dress someone, does not deprive someone of liberty. Emergencies could include disturbed, threatening or self harming behaviour.
Have relatives or carers asked for the person to be discharged to their care, and has this request been refused?
Have relatives or carers been refused access to the person, or had severe restrictions put on their access? Reasonable restrictions on visiting hours etc. are not relevant.

Has the person been prevented from spending time with the people who matter to them? This would for instance include preventing the person from spending time with friends inside or outside the home/ward. It would not include guiding the person away from casual acquaintances who appear to be abusing or exploiting the person, or reasonable restrictions on the times when the person can socialise with friends, for instance because of the pattern of the establishment's daily routine.

. Is the way the person's care is organised, severely restrictive in what they can do in other ways? An example of a severe restriction could be placing the person for a large proportion of their waking time in a position which prevents them from moving (eg. Using furniture which they cannot get up from). It would not be a severe restriction to use furniture designed to keep the person safe, which they cannot get up from unaided, if they are usually able to get help to get out of it when they show a persistent or purposeful desire to do so

data.text: Appendix 4: The six assessments

When a supervisory body receives a request for authorisation of deprivation of liberty they must obtain 6 assessments. These assessments must usually be completed within 21 days of the supervisory body receiving the request for the authorisation but, if an urgent authorisation has been given, the assessments must be completed before the expiry of the urgent authorisation (i.e. within seven days).
The six assessments are:

table_items.text: The person must be aged 18 or over

The hospital must ensure that the authorisation sought does not conflict with a valid decision by a donee of Lasting Power of Attorney (“an attorney”), or by a deputy appointed for the person by the Court of Protection (a “deputy”), and is not for the purpose of giving treatment that would conflict with a valid and applicable advance decision made by the person.
To confirm that the person lacks capacity to make the decision on whether to be admitted to or remain in hospital
Needed to demonstrate whether the person is suffering from a mental disorder

A person is eligible unless they are: -detained under the Mental Health Act 1983, - subject to a requirement under the Mental Health Act 1983 that conflicts with the authorisation sought e.g. a guardianship order requiring them to live somewhere else, - subject to powers of recall under the Mental Health Act 1983. or - unless the application is to enable mental health treatment in hospital and they object to being in hospital or to the treatment in question. In deciding whether a person objects, their past and present behaviour, wishes, feelings, views, beliefs and values should be considered where relevant.

By a trained BIA to ensure that whilst the proposed course of action would constitute a deprivation of liberty it is: - in the best interests of the person to be subject to the authorisation, and - necessary in order to prevent harm to them; and a proportionate response to the likelihood of suffering harm and the seriousness of that harm.

The regulations cover, among other things, the qualifications, skills and training needed to be an assessor, the need for there to be at least two assessors (best interests and mental health assessments must be carried out by different assessors), and the need for the best interests assessor to be independent of the admissions/care planning process.

data.text: Appendix 5: Use of hand control mittens
Use of hand control mittens

Patients in the acute phase of their illness frequently become restless and unintentionally remove feeding tubes and other essential access lines. There are various treatment options which include forms of restraint, and as such, are ethically sensitive and fraught with emotion for the patient, their family and for staff. This should be managed alongside the need to provide optimal treatment such as hand control mittens, which should be considered if patients have removed essential lines or tubes. There is no definitive number of incidences which will trigger assessment and the decision about need for assessment. This should be based upon clinical judgment and best interests of the patient.
The Trust does NOT condone the use of bandaging to restrict hand movement in patients who remove tubes/lines.

Staffs are required to consider the patient's capacity to be involved in the decision-making process and where at all possible gain the patient's consent. Patients and their relatives or carers should be involved in the decision making process and provided with appropriate information. The views of patients and relatives must be used in the decision making process and documented in the patients' health record.
A review should be made of the patient's mental capacity and the use of the mittens each time the condition changes or at least every 24 hours.
Criteria for the use of Hand Control Mittens.
* Nasal Gastric tube
* Tracheostomy
* CPAP
* Arterial line
* CVP line
* High flow oxygen.

There is no definitive number of incidences which will trigger assessment for the use of hand control mittens. Criteria for assessment should be based upon clinical judgement and in the best interests of the patient.
Patients who have capacity can consent to the use of the mittens. However, if a patient has capacity refuses to allow the use of the mittens then they MUST NOT be used on the patient.
If the patient has no next of kin an IMCA should be considered to be present at the meeting. Conclusions of all discussions and decisions should be clearly documented in the medical notes.
Contraindications to the use of Hand Control Mittens Hand control mittens should not be used on patients who:
* are highly aggressive and likely to be violent.
* are suicidal.
* has a wound site or abrasions on both or either hands.
* has severe arthritis of the wrist or hand.
* has a radial renal fistula.
* has a dislocation or fracture to either hand.
* has an intravenous cannula inserted to the back of either hand or forearm.
Application of Hand Control Mittens
Prior to the application of the hand control mitten the medical professional has to check:
Removal of the Hand Mittens
If any of the following occur the use of hand mittens has to be reassessed.

What are you proposing to change?
This is a review of an existing guideline that now reflects the new MSE Structure and unification of practice across all 3 sites.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

To ensure appropriate guidelines are in place to support staff at a service level and to ensure best interest decisions are required to deprive someone of there liberty in order to provide required care. To ensure the guidance is applicable to all appropriate services within the MSE Group.
Who benefits from this change and how?

All individuals over the age of 18 who do not have the capacity to make the decision to remain in hospital to receive required care. Staff – To support staff at a service level and to ensure best interest decisions are undertaken within statutory requirements and any restrictive interventions to ensure someone remains in hospital to receive care are within a legal framework.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No – The policy is clear as to which patient groups / individuals this policy applies to.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
This is part of a statutory duty under the Mental Capacity Act 2005. Relevant professionals consulted.
